reasoning:
This one falls outside my circle of competence. I’ve spent my life buying simple, cash-generating businesses I can understand – soda pop, insurance, railroads – not digital content factories. When I don’t understand the economics, I pass. 

1. Circle of Competence: Streaming video is a fast-changing, capital-intensive business with thin margins and constant content bidding wars. I can’t model subscriber churn or content hit rates reliably, so I stay away. 
2. Moat: Netflix has brand recognition and scale, but as soon as Disney, Amazon and others decided to build their own services, it lost exclusivity on marquee titles. Its moat looks more like a sandcastle that needs constant rebuilding. 
3. Management: Hastings and company are creative operators, but producing original shows means huge upfront costs and unpredictable returns. They’re smart folks, but I’d prefer managers with a track record of allocating capital in simple, proven businesses. 
4. Financial Health: We have no dependable numbers here – the data provided is nil. My rule: ‘Rule No.1, never lose money. Rule No.2, never forget rule No.1.’ With no visibility on cash flow or debt, I can’t risk my owners’ capital. 
5. Valuation: Without an intrinsic estimate or margin of safety, I’m flying blind. Price is what you pay; value is what you get. I can’t tell what I’m getting. 
6. Long Term Prospects: A decade from now, competition will only be stiffer, content costs higher, and subscriber fatigue a real threat. That’s not a durable franchise in my book. 
7. Portfolio Comparison: I’d rather hold a wonderful business like Coca-Cola or Bank of America at a fair price than try to guess wins and losses in Hollywood. For me, this opportunity earns a polite ‘no thank you.’ There’s no shame in saying ‘I don’t understand it enough to invest.’
